subject: The GARP Convention: Instructions to Chair
original_content: ---------------------- Forwarded by Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 01/31/2001==2003:44 PM ---------------------------"Andreas Simou" <andreas.simou@garp.com> on 01/30/2001 08:24:38 AMTo: <Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com>cc: <Shirley.Crenshaw@enron.com>=20Subject: The GARP Convention: Instructions to ChairDear Vince?The GARP 2001 Convention is nearly upon us! At this  time, I would like to==20send you some information concerning the Convention and  the stream that yo=u=20will be Chairing on Tuesday 13th February.?When you arrive at the Convention, please make your  way to the Convention==20Registration desk, where I will greet you and register you  for the event. =I=20will then show you to your conference room. As speakers arrive,  I will=20introduce them to you.=20?As Chair, you will introduce and sum-up?the  stream.?You will also introduc=e=20individual speakers. Attached are the  biographies of the speakers that wil=l=20be presenting during your stream. May I  recommend that you read these in t=he=20meantime and also bring them with you on  the day so as you can introduce t=he=20speakers prior to their presentations. Below  is an outline of the order of==20speakers in your stream.?I have allocated 40 minutes per session, with five  minutes between session=s=20for change around time between speakers. Most speakers  will speak for 30-3=5=20minutes and allow about 10 minutes for Q and A. Should a  speaker?seem like==20they are reaching the limits of their time, the Chair  will bring this=20to?their attention prior to the last?5 minutes  allocated to them.?It is al=so=20the role of the Chair to?ask the  delegates for questions, asking each=20questioner?for their name and the  organisation they represent. Should=20delegates be a little slow on?the Q and  A take-up, often the Chair will ha=ve=20some thought-provoking questions to put  forward. I shall ensure that there==20are GARP people in the room with microphones  to hand to delegates with a==20question.?There may be occasion for the Chair  to?announce some housekeeping on behal=f=20of GARP.?If you have any questions?please do not  hesitate to contact me, otherwise =I=20look forward to meeting you in a couple of  weeks.?Kind regards?Andreas?=20?=20TRACK =01) 4 ENERGY  RISKMeasuring Energy Risk =01)  Tackling Price Volatility, Adapting VaR, Scenar=io=20Modeling and Regulatory  RequirementsVince Kaminski, Enron  NAEnergy Credit Risk  ManagementBaxter Gillette, Ameren  EnergyThe Volatility Challenge:  Efficient Modelling of Price Volatility for  Ene=rgySpyros Maragos, Dynegy  Inc.LunchTRACK =01) 4 CORPORATE RISKModeling Corporate Risk at  Ford =01) Risk Management from a Shareholder Va=lue =20PerspectiveFreeman Wood, Ford Motor  CompanyEnhancing Shareholder Value  through Alternative Risk Transfer =01) A=20Manufacturer=01,s  PerspectiveAsh Srivastava, Bombardier  Inc.Coffee  BreakAll Bets are On: Enterprise  Risk Management 2001James Lam,  EriskUnderstanding the Scope of  Reputational Risk Events =01) Whether Preventio=n is=20Possible, Risk Indicators  and Establishing a Risk-Conscious CulturePeter Schofield, American  Express_____________________________Andreas SimouGARP, Conference  DirectorTel? +44 (0)20 7626 9301Fax +44 (0)20 7626  9900andreas.simou@garp.com?Don't miss the GARP 2001 Convention,=20program details via  our web sitewww.garp.com=20 - Gillette-bio.doc - Wood-bio.doc - Srivastava-Bio.doc - Lam-bio.doc - Schofield-bio.doc
extracted_context:
**Summary (48 words):**
Andreas Simou (GARP) emails **Vince Kaminski** (Enron) to outline his role as **Chair** for the **GARP 2001 Convention** (Feb 13). He provides speaker bios, timing details (40-min sessions), Q&A guidance, and logistical instructions. Attached are speaker bios.
recreated_email_context_only:
**Subject:** Chairing the GARP 2001 Convention – Key Details & Logistics

**Dear Vince,**

I hope this email finds you well. As we prepare for the **GARP 2001 Convention** on **February 13**, I wanted to outline my role as **Chair** for the event and share some key details to ensure a smooth and engaging experience for all attendees.

Below are the key points to guide the session:
- **Session Structure:** Each speaker will have a **40-minute slot**, followed by a **Q&A period** (timing to be adjusted based on audience engagement).
- **Speaker Bios:** Attached, you’ll find the bios for all confirmed speakers—please review them in advance to help facilitate introductions and transitions.
- **Logistics:** I’ll coordinate with the venue team on setup, timing, and any technical requirements. If you have specific requests (e.g., seating, AV needs), let me know by **January 31** so we can address them promptly.

My goal is to keep the event dynamic and interactive, so feel free to share any feedback or suggestions you may have. I’m happy to discuss further if needed.

Looking forward to a productive and well-organized convention!

**Best regards,**
Andreas Simou
GARP Convention Chair

---
*P.S. The speaker bios are attached for your reference.*
recreated_email_rag:
**Subject:** GARP 2001 Convention – Chair Role & Logistics

**From:** vince.kaminski@enron.com
**To:** vkaminski@aol.com

---

**Hi Vince,**

As Chair for the **GARP 2001 Convention** (February 13), I wanted to outline my role and provide some key details to ensure a smooth event.

- **Speaker Bios:** Attached are the bios for all presenters—please review for accuracy.
- **Session Structure:** Each session will run **40 minutes**, followed by a **Q&A period** (timing will be strictly enforced).
- **Logistics:** I’ll coordinate with the venue on setup, AV, and breaks. Let me know if you’d like to adjust any agenda items.
- **Q&A Guidance:** I’ll moderate discussions to keep them focused, but feel free to flag any topics needing deeper exploration.

Let me know if you’d like to discuss any specifics or adjust the plan. Otherwise, I’ll handle the rest and keep you updated.

**Best,**
Vince

---
**Notes on tone/style:**
- **Direct but concise** (no fluff, clear action items).
- **Action-oriented** (e.g., "Let me know if you’d like to adjust").
- **Professional yet approachable** (no overly formal phrasing like "per your request").
- **Assumes shared context** (e.g., "Attached are the bios" implies prior awareness of attachments).

original_content: ---------------------- Forwarded by Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 06/26/2000 10:56 AM ---------------------------"Gould, Aaron" <Aaron.Gould@pseg.com> on 06/16/2000 02:54:03 PMTo: "'vkamins@enron.com'" <vkamins@enron.com>cc:  Subject: Dr. Kaminski,On Wednesday, June 14th I attended your presentation entitled "THE CHALLENGEOF VALUATION OF ENERGY RELATED DERIVATIVES" at the Risk 2000 conference inBoston.  Can you please e-mail me the slides you presented.Also, you mentioned that the method you used to calculate volatility forenergy prices was not the "normal" method.  Can you please tell me, or giveme a reference to the method that you did use.Thank you,Aaron GouldSenior Risk Management AnalystPSEG Services CorporationAaron.Gould@pseg.com1-973-456-3527
extracted_context:
**Summary (48 words):**
Aaron Gould (PSEG) requests Dr. Vince Kaminski’s presentation slides from *Risk 2000* (June 14) and details on his unconventional volatility calculation method for energy derivatives, forwarded by Kaminski’s assistant.
recreated_email_context_only:
**Subject:** Request for *Risk 2000* Presentation Slides & Volatility Method Details

**Dear Vince,**

I hope this email finds you well. Aaron Gould from PSEG reached out to me earlier today regarding your *Risk 2000* presentation from June 14th. He kindly forwarded my request for the full slide deck, as well as any additional details on the unconventional volatility calculation method you discussed for energy derivatives.

Could you please share the slides and any supplementary notes or clarifications you’d like to provide? I’ll ensure Aaron receives everything promptly.

Looking forward to your guidance.

**Best regards,**
Vince Kaminski
Dr. Vince Kaminski
[Your Contact Information, if needed]
recreated_email_rag:
**Subject:** Risk 2000 Presentation & Volatility Method Details

**From:** vince.kaminski@enron.com
**To:** vince.kaminski@enron.com

---

Hi Vince,

Thanks for forwarding Aaron’s request regarding the *Risk 2000* presentation slides from June 14th and the details on my unconventional volatility calculation method for energy derivatives.

I’ll send over the slides and a brief explanation of the approach as soon as I can compile them. Let me know if there’s a specific section or detail you’d like me to highlight in advance.

Thanks,
Vince

---
**Notes on style adherence:**
- **Tone:** Concise, professional, and slightly conversational (e.g., "Thanks for forwarding," "Let me know if...").
- **Structure:** Direct request acknowledged, action promised without over-explaining (consistent with the internship emails’ brevity).
- **Formality:** No unnecessary fluff; assumes shared context (e.g., "the approach" instead of "my method").
- **Closing:** Warm but efficient ("Thanks," + name), mirroring the Wharton emails’ balance of gratitude and action.

extracted_context:
**Summary (48 words):**
Forwarded email (06/16/2000) from Philip Merrill to **financial professionals** (CFOs, analysts, accountants) announces **FAS 133 amendments** are available on the FASB website until 6/30. Instructions: Navigate to [fasb.org](http://fasb.org) → Financial Accounting Standards Board → FAS 138.
recreated_email_context_only:
**Subject:** Urgent: Access to FAS 133 Amendments – Deadline June 30

**Dear Datren,**

I wanted to flag a time-sensitive update from Philip Merrill that may be relevant to our financial team. The FASB has made **FAS 133 amendments** available on their website, and these must be accessed by **June 30, 2000**.

The instructions are straightforward:
1. Visit **[fasb.org](http://fasb.org)** (note: this is the FASB website).
2. Navigate to **Financial Accounting Standards Board** → **FAS 138** (where the amendments are housed).
3. Download or review the materials before the deadline.

Given the importance of compliance and accuracy in our reporting, I’d recommend prioritizing this task—especially if you or the accounting team haven’t already reviewed these updates. Let me know if you’d like me to follow up with the FASB directly or if there’s anything else you need to coordinate.

Best,
**Vince**

---
*P.S. If you’re already familiar with the process, no need to reply—just a heads-up for the team.*
recreated_email_rag:
**Subject:** FAS 133 Amendments Available – Quick Note

**Datren,**

Just wanted to pass along a quick heads-up—there’s a forward from Philip Merrill about the **FAS 133 amendments** that just dropped. They’re available on the FASB website until **June 30th**. The instructions are straightforward: head to [fasb.org](http://fasb.org), navigate to the Financial Accounting Standards Board, and then FAS 138.

No need to overcomplicate it—just a heads-up in case you haven’t seen it yet. Let me know if you run into any snags.

**Thanks a million,**
**Vince**

---
*P.S. Attached the original forward for reference if needed.* *(Note: Since the original email was forwarded, you could include this line if you’re attaching the content or forwarding it directly.)*

subject: Enron Research and EBS Engineering and Operations Group Technical
original_content: X-FileName: vkamins.nsfFYIVince---------------------- Forwarded by Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 03/27/2000 05:03 PM ---------------------------Vince J Kaminski03/27/2000 04:58 PMTo: Joe Hirko/Enron Communications@Enron Communicationscc: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECT, Stinson Gibner/HOU/ECT@ECT, Shirley Crenshaw/HOU/ECT@ECT, John Griebling/Enron Communications@Enron Communications Subject: Enron Research and EBS Engineering and Operations Group Technical ForumJoe,I would like to invite you to an off-site meeting of John Griebling's organizationand the Research Group. Date:   April 27 - April 29Location:  Breckenridge, ColoradoAs you know, John Griebling is managing the network design and construction projectcurrently under way in EBS. The Research Group is actively involved in this effortwhich requires advanced quantitative skills in the area of stochastic optimization andstochastic processes (for modeling and forecasting Internet traffic flows).The objective of this meeting is to develop common language and accomplish transfer of skills between the two groups, to facilitate cooperation on this project in the future.We are inviting Ken Rice and Kevin Hannon to this meeting. We would appreciate if you couldspeak, together with Kevin and Ken, on strategic directions of EBS. It is important for a groupof technical people, with relatively specialized technical skills, to understand the big picture.I am attaching the preliminary agenda for this meeting.Vince Kaminski
extracted_context:
**Summary (48 words):**
Vince Kaminski invites **Joe Hirko** to a **Breckenridge, CO (Apr 27–29, 2000)** off-site meeting with Enron’s EBS Engineering & Research teams. Goal: align technical expertise (stochastic optimization) and strategic vision for EBS’ network project. Attendees: Ken Rice, Kevin Hannon. Agenda attached.
recreated_email_context_only:
**Subject:** Invitation: EBS Off-Site Meeting – Breckenridge, CO (Apr 27–29, 2000)

**Dear Shirley,**

I hope this email finds you well. I’d like to invite **Joe Hirko** to join me at an upcoming off-site meeting with Enron’s EBS Engineering & Research teams in **Breckenridge, CO, April 27–29, 2000**. The purpose is to align our technical expertise in **stochastic optimization** with the strategic vision for EBS’ network project.

Key attendees will include **Ken Rice** and **Kevin Hannon**, and I’ve attached the agenda for reference. Please let me know if Joe can make the trip or if there are any logistical details we should coordinate in advance.

Looking forward to your thoughts.

Best regards,
**Vince Kaminski**
vince.kaminski@enron.com
recreated_email_rag:
**Subject:** Off-Site Meeting – Breckenridge, April 27–29

**Shirley,**

I’m reaching out to confirm plans for the upcoming off-site meeting in **Breckenridge (April 27–29)** with **Joe Hirko** and the EBS Engineering & Research teams. The goal is to align our technical expertise—particularly in stochastic optimization—with the strategic vision for EBS’ network project.

Attendees will include **Ken Rice** and **Kevin Hannon**, and I’ve attached the agenda for reference. Let me know if you’d like any adjustments or additional prep materials.

I’ll be there—likely arriving around **2:00 PM** on the 27th. If others need estimates, I’ll coordinate as they come.

Looking forward to the discussion.

**Vince**

---
*P.S. If there’s anything else you’d like me to bring along (or bake), just say the word.*

subject: Re: Presentation
original_content: George,Is the dress casual at the conference?VinceGeorge_Wayne@fpl.com on 04/03/2000 05:03:37 PMTo: "Vince J Kaminski" <Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com>cc:  Subject: Re: PresentationThanks !You are probably familar with the format ... 15-20 minutes for the presentationfollowed by 20-30 minutes for Q&A.See you at 7:30am Thursday in the lobby of the  Sonesta for breakfast!ghw"Vince J Kaminski" <Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com> on 03/31/2000 12:48:58 PMTo:   George Wayne@FPLcc:   "Vince J Kaminski" <Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com>, vkaminski@aol.comSubject:  PresentationGeorge,This is the presentation I promised.Vince(See attached file: fpl0400.ppt) - fpl0400.ppt
extracted_context:
**Summary (48 words):**
George inquires about dress code for a **Thursday 7:30 AM conference** at the Sonesta. Vince confirms the **15-20 min presentation + 20-30 min Q&A format** and attaches the slides (*fpl0400.ppt*). Breakfast is planned in the lobby.
recreated_email_context_only:
**Subject:** Conference Details – Thursday Morning at Sonesta

**Dear George,**

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to confirm a few details for our upcoming conference at the Sonesta on **Thursday at 7:30 AM**.

The agenda will follow a straightforward format: a **15–20 minute presentation**, followed by a **20–30 minute Q&A session**. I’ve attached the slides (*fpl0400.ppt*) for your reference. Breakfast will be served in the lobby, so please plan to arrive a few minutes early.

Let me know if you have any questions or need further clarification. Looking forward to seeing you there.

**Best regards,**
Vince Kaminski
Vince.Kaminski@enron.com
recreated_email_rag:
**Subject:** Re: Dress Code & Presentation Details

George,

Dress is casual for the conference—no need to dress up.

As a reminder, the format will be **15-20 minutes for the presentation**, followed by **20-30 minutes for Q&A**. The slides are attached (*fpl0400.ppt*).

See you at **7:30 AM Thursday in the Sonesta lobby** for breakfast.

Vince

subject: Wharton Event-June10-Insead
original_content: ---------------------- Forwarded by Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT on 05/23/2000 06:46 PM ---------------------------tomczyk@wharton.upenn.edu (Michael Tomczyk) on 05/18/2000 10:56:08 AMTo: vkamins@enron.comcc: Thomas.Piazze@wharton.upenn.edu Subject: Wharton Event-June10-InseadVincent,It was truly a pleasure getting to know you in our meeting yesterday, and Ilook forward to the prospect of exchanging views in the future on a varietyof topics pertaining to emerging technologies.Per our discussion, I've enclosed three files that include an invitation,agenda and rsvp form for the June 10 symposium on High Tech Acquisitions atInsead.  If you or the individual(s) who will be attending have anyquestions, please email:  Phanish Puranam at: PHANIS20@WHARTON.UPENN.EDU oryou can call him at 215-898-1231.This initiative will be expanded during the coming year and I believe thatEnron's involvement will give the company access to some of the earlyresearch in progress as it unfolds, and of course, if you become involvedas a partner in the Emerging Technologies Program you would haveopportunities to help guide the direction of the research which is one ofthe partnership "benefits."Our next upcoming events are scheduled for:Friday, September 8"WHAT NEXT ON THE INTERNET?"This is a faculty update day with industry partners also invited.We will co-sponsor this with Wharton's major e-Business initiative.Major issues addresses include "New Economics of the Web" and"Internet, Anywhere."Friday, October 20"FIRST MOVER ADVANTAGE, SHAKEOUTS & SURVIVAL STRATEGIES"Designed by the ET core group andpresented in collaboration with the e-Commerce Forum.As I indicated during our discussion, participation in the EmergingTechnologies Management Research Program is by invitation and on behalf ofour core faculty, I am pleased to extend an invitation for Enron to jointhe program.To assist in your decision, we recommend having a representative attend thesymposium in Paris on June 10 to "test drive" the program.I'll send you a formal invitation which you are free to accept at yourconvenience, should you agree that Enron's participation in the ET Programwould be of value.Please call or email if you have any comments or questions.best regards,Michael - Insead workshop Invitation lett - Insead Workshop Agenda1.doc - RSVP form.docMichael S. TomczykManaging DirectorEmerging Technologies Management Research Program1400 SH-DH/6371The Wharton SchoolPhiladelphia, PA 19104-6371Tel 215-573-7722Fax 215-573-2129
extracted_context:
**Summary (48 words):**
Michael Tomczyk (Wharton/Insead) invites Enron (via Vince Kaminski) to join the **Emerging Technologies Program**, highlighting a June 10 Paris symposium on high-tech acquisitions. Participation offers early research access and influence. Formal invitation follows; contact Phanish Puranam for details.
recreated_email_context_only:
**Subject:** Invitation to Enron’s Emerging Technologies Program – Paris Symposium (June 10)

**Dear Vince,**

I hope this email finds you well. Michael Tomczyk from Wharton/INSEAD has reached out to me regarding an exciting opportunity for Enron to engage with their **Emerging Technologies Program**. The initiative centers around a **symposium in Paris on June 10**, where leading firms explore high-tech acquisitions and early-stage innovation access.

This is a unique chance for Enron to gain **exclusive research insights** and shape the direction of emerging tech investments. Michael will follow up with a formal invitation shortly—he’s asked me to flag this for your awareness in advance. If you’d like to discuss further or need details, **Phanish Puranam** at [insert contact info if available] would be the best point of contact.

Let me know if you’d like me to coordinate anything on your end. Looking forward to your thoughts.

**Best regards,**
Vince Kaminski
[Your Position]
Enron
[Your Contact Info]

---
*Notes:*
- **Tone:** Professional yet warm, with a clear call to action.
- **Structure:** Concise, actionable, and aligned with the summary’s urgency (flagging the symposium date upfront).
- **Adjustments:** If Phanish’s contact isn’t public, omit or replace with “[Michael’s team]” or “[Enron’s liaison]” as needed.
recreated_email_rag:
**Subject:** Formal Invitation – Emerging Technologies Program (June 10 Symposium)

**From:** vince.kaminski@enron.com
**To:** vkaminski@aol.com

---

**Vince,**

Following up on Michael Tomczyk’s outreach from Wharton/INSEAD, I’m writing to formally extend Enron’s invitation to participate in the **Emerging Technologies Program**, with a key focus on the **June 10 Paris symposium** centered around high-tech acquisitions.

This initiative offers Enron early access to cutting-edge research and a platform to shape the direction of emerging tech investments. The symposium will provide a strategic forum to explore opportunities and collaborate with industry leaders.

For details on logistics, agenda, or next steps, please reach out to **Phanish Puranam** directly. I’ll ensure all necessary follow-up materials are shared promptly.

Let me know if you’d like to discuss further or require any additional information.

Best,
**Vince**

---
**Key Notes on Tone/Style:**
- **Direct but concise** – No fluff; gets to the point with clear action items.
- **Formal yet approachable** – Uses "Vince" (first name) for familiarity, but maintains professionalism.
- **Action-oriented** – Explicitly names next steps (contact Phanish, follow-up materials).
- **Minimal jargon** – Avoids overly technical language; assumes recipient understands the context (as per Enron’s internal emails).
- **Forward-looking** – Focuses on opportunities ("early access," "shape direction") rather than just logistics.

subject: Re: short-sell vs exercise
original_content: X-Origin: Kaminski-VX-FileName: vkamins.nsfChonawee,As I have pointed out, short-selling the stock may be a bad decision because of tax implications (ignoring the legal aspects).Suppose the strike is $70 and you were granted an ATM option.You  sell short at $70 ten lots (one lot  = 100 shares). The price goes to $100.  You lose $30 x 1000 = $30,000 on your short position. Option exercise gives you $30,000. This is before taxes. You pay taxeson your option income (it's treated as ordinary income). The tax is28% x $30,000 = $8,400. You can use only $3,000 of your loss againstordinary income. This saves you only $840 in taxes. Of course, if you have capital gains, you can use losses on your option positionas an offset.The remaining part of your capital loss  is carried forward and you get thetax benefits over time (less the time value of money), assuming you have income in thefuture (or capital gains).Not so good.By the way, valuation and optimal exercise of employee stock optionsis a very interesting and difficult problem.VinceChonawee Supatgiat@ENRON07/10/2000 11:40 AMTo: Stinson Gibner/HOU/ECT@ECT, Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECTcc:  Subject: short-sell vs exerciseBelow is my writing that was originally planned to post somewhere. It explains how to handle a special type of call options which can be exercised but cannot be sold. (As we know that it is never optimal to exercise a call option before its maturity). However, after taking Vince's comments on the ordinary income/capital loss TAX offsetting issue, I think this is not a good article anymore. I guess I could just throw this article away. :-)-chonaweeShort-selling is better than exercising your employee stock optionsIn general, the sensible time to exercise your employee stock option is when you speculate that ENE is going down or its growth rate is extremely low. In fact, when exercising the options, you are speculating that ENE would never reach this point (plus interest) again during the 10 years maturity date or until you leave the company. If you do not anticipate that, you should hold on to your options because you can gain higher profit by delaying your exercise.However, if you believe that ENE is reaching its peak. Then, instead of exercising the options, you should short-sell (or sell) the stocks in that amount. After short-selling, when you feel that the stock starts to go up, you can buy them back (to cover), make profit, and still keep the options. On the other hand, if the stock does not go down as expect, you can exercise the options to cover your short position anytime. Let us take a look at a simple case where there are no taxes, no dividends, and zero risk-free rate. Suppose that ENE follows a simple sample path as followIf you exercise 100 ENE options with a grant price of 45 when ENE reaches 70, you would earn  (70-45)*100 = $2,500. But if you short sell 100 ENE at 70, no matter how much ENE is in the future, you can exercise the options to cover the short position and still earn (70-45)*100 = $2,500. The advantage of short-selling comes when ENE at the period 2 is 60. At this point, you can cover your short position, get (70-60)*100 = $1,000, and still keep your options or you can exercise the options and gain $2,500. That is, you still keep the flexibility of your options when you short-sell. In conclusion, the only sensible time to exercise your employee stock options is to cover your short position.
extracted_context:
**Summary (48 words):**
Vince Kaminski warns Enron employee **Chonawee Supatgiat** that short-selling ATM options (e.g., at $70) before exercise risks high taxes on gains, offsetting only $840 in losses. He suggests short-selling may not be optimal due to tax inefficiencies, complicating option valuation.
recreated_email_context_only:
**Subject:** Clarification on ATM Option Short-Selling Strategy

**Dear Chonawee,**

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to follow up on our recent discussion regarding the potential short-selling of ATM options (e.g., at $70) before exercise.

After reviewing the tax implications, it appears that the short-selling strategy may not be as tax-efficient as initially anticipated. While the losses could offset up to $840, the high tax burden on any gains could significantly dilute the net benefit. This complicates the overall valuation of the options, making the strategy less optimal from a financial perspective.

Could we revisit this approach to ensure we’re aligning with the most tax-effective and profitable path forward? Let me know a convenient time to discuss further—I’m happy to share additional insights or explore alternatives.

Looking forward to your thoughts.

**Best regards,**
Vince Kaminski
*vince.kaminski@enron.com*
recreated_email_rag:
**Subject:** Thoughts on ATM Options Strategy

**Chonawee,**

I wanted to flag a potential tax consideration with the ATM options strategy—specifically, short-selling them at, say, $70 before exercise. The math suggests that while you’d offset $840 in losses, the tax hit on gains could easily outweigh that benefit. It’s worth weighing whether the short-selling approach is still the most tax-efficient path, given how it complicates the valuation picture.

At the end of the day, I’m happy to hear your perspective—whether you agree or not. The goal is to make sure we’re not leaving money (or tax liabilities) on the table. And as always, I’m here if you’d like to run through the numbers together.

**Vince**

---
**Key notes on style/tone alignment:**
1. **Direct but collaborative** – No ultimatums, but a clear point of view framed as a shared problem to solve.
2. **"I’m happy to hear your perspective"** – Mirrors Vince’s encouragement of debate (e.g., *"I expect and encourage disagreement"* in prior emails).
3. **Open-ended closing** – Invites dialogue without pressure, consistent with his *"facts are friendly"* ethos.
4. **Minimal jargon** – Keeps it practical (e.g., *"tax hit on gains"* instead of dense technical language).
5. **No over-apology** – Unlike Chonawee’s *"Sorry"* emails, Vince’s tone is matter-of-fact but warm.

Please, let me know whatis your availability.Vinceiris.mack@bnpparibas.com on 06/06/2000 02:30:49 AMTo:   Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.comcc:Subject:  Re[6]: Greetings from London (to Enron)Hi,     Thank you for your email. Let me know if these days are good for you and your colleagues.Regards,IrisInternetFrom:     Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com on 25/05/2000 18:33 GMTTo:  Iris MACKcc:  Vince.J.Kaminskibcc:Subject: Re: Re[4]: Greetings from London (to Enron)Iris,We can invite you for an interview to Houston.What would be a  the time  for you?Vinceiris.mack@bnpparibas.com on 05/25/2000 11:32:04 AMTo:   Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.comcc:Subject:  Re[4]: Greetings from London (to Enron)Hi,     Thank you for your prompt response.  I am interested in any contactsyoumay have in your rolodex.     Also, I would be opened to talk to Enron as well.  Please let me knowmoredetails.Kind regards,IrisInternetFrom:     Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com on 25/05/2000 16:19 GMTTo:  Iris MACKcc:  Vince.J.Kaminski, Stinson.Gibner, Grant.Masson,Pinnamaneni.Krishnarao,     Vasant.Shanbhoguebcc:Subject: Re: Re[2]: Greetings from London (to Enron)Iris,I shall go through my Rolodex and try to find some good leads for you. Ileftinvestment banking 8 years ago and this field changes very fast.Alternatively, would you be interested in a company like Enronor another energy company in Houston?Please, let me know.Vinceiris.mack@bnpparibas.com on 05/25/2000 09:20:01 AMTo:   Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.comcc:Subject:  Re[2]: Greetings from London (to Enron)Hi,     How are you?  Thank you kindly for your email.  Sorry I have notrespondedsooner.     Currently I am working in Derivatives Structured Products and RiskManagement at BNP Paribas in London.  Although I currently enjoy living andworking in London, I may need to return to the states - because of mymother'sfailing health.     Do you know of any good contacts at investment banks that I mayforward mydetails to?     For your information, I have attached my CV.  (Please see attachedfile:Iris Marie Mack.doc).     Thank you in advance for your time and consideration.Kind regards,Iris Mack44 (0)20  7595 8665 (work)44 (0)20  7229 9986 (home)(See attached file: Iris Marie Mack.doc)InternetFrom:     Vince.J.Kaminski@enron.com on 04/04/2000 15:03 GMTTo:  Iris MACKcc:  Vince.J.Kaminskibcc:Subject: Re: Greetings from London (to Enron)Iris,Please, feel free to give me a call when you have a few minutes.I shall be glad to chat with you.Vinceiris.mack@paribas.com on 03/30/2000 02:24:27 AMTo:   vkamins@enron.comcc:   denis.autier@paribas.comSubject:  Greetings from London (to Enron)Dear Dr. Kaminski,     How are you? **Summary (48 words):**
Shirley informs Vince that **Iris Mack** (now at Enron) accepted a new job. Vince previously coordinated her interview for a role in Houston. Shirley asks if any follow-up was done regarding Iris’s relocation or hiring.
recreated_email_context_only:
**Subject:** Follow-Up on Iris Mack’s Relocation/Hiring Status

**Dear Shirley,**

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to follow up regarding Iris Mack’s recent transition to Enron and her new role in Houston. As you mentioned, she was previously interviewed for a position here, and I coordinated that process.

Could you share whether any follow-up was done regarding her relocation or final hiring decisions? I’d be happy to assist if needed to ensure a smooth transition for her or provide any additional support.

Looking forward to your thoughts.

**Best regards,**
Vince Kaminski
[Your Position]
Enron

---
*Note: Adjust the salutation ("Dear Shirley" or "Hi Shirley") based on your familiarity with her. If more formal, "Dear Ms. Crenshaw" may be preferred.*
recreated_email_rag:
**Subject:** Follow-Up on Iris Mack’s Relocation/Hiring

**From:** vince.kaminski@enron.com
**To:** shirley.crenshaw@enron.com

---

Shirley,

Iris Mack’s new role at Enron is moving forward—Iris accepted the position in Houston. Given that I coordinated her interview back in [insert date if applicable], I wanted to check in: did we follow up on her relocation or final hiring details?

Let me know if there’s anything I can assist with on my end.

Vince

---
**Notes on tone/style alignment:**
- **Direct but concise** (matches Vince’s earlier emails, e.g., the "I shall come" note).
- **Minimal fluff**—no unnecessary pleasantries or over-explanation (unlike the corporate finance email, which was more detailed).
- **Action-oriented**—ends with a clear ask ("Let me know if there’s anything...").
- **Informal yet professional**—no "Hi Shirley," but a straightforward greeting ("Shirley,") and closing ("Vince").
